Case: Kimberly Brasher – Premise 2-25-2023. Client: Kimberly Brasher.

On September 20, 2023, at 10:06 AM, Jessica Bottorff of The Whaley Law Firm emailed Deaconess Medical Records with the subject “Kimberly Brasher [EXTERNAL EMAIL]” and cc’d KimberlyBrasherSFZ3954564@louisvilleaccidentlawyer.filevineapp.com. The body stated that attached was a request for records and bills on their client, Kimberly Brasher, and it was signed by The Whaley Law Firm. The email carried external-sender notices and security banners indicating it was an external email and advising caution with attachments or links.

The next day, September 21, 2023, at 7:58 AM, the message chain was forwarded to include a reply from Pamela Newman. In her original response dated September 20, 2023 at 4:13 PM, Ms. Newman informed the requester that the Authorization was not dated and instructed them to resubmit with a dated authorization. She added an important note: as of October 1, 2023, all requests would be pre-pay only and payment must be made before records would be released. She then provided the procedures for submitting future requests: send all records requests to Deaconess Midtown Hospital via fax at 812-450-8124 or to her email for faster service, noting that she processes requests for Deaconess Clinic’s, Deaconess Midtown Hospital, and Deaconess Gateway Hospital. Her signature block included the following details: Pamela J. Newman, ROI/Medical Records Specialist III; Email: Pamela.Newman@hcrsolutions.com; Direct Line: (812) 450-7576; Legal Medical Records: (812) 450-2154; Fax: (812) 450-8124; and the mailing address 1419 W. Lloyd Expressway, Suite 101, Evansville, Indiana 47710.

The forwarded chain also included the original message from Jessica Bottorff stating, “Attached is a request for records & bills on our client, Kimberly Brasher,” and identified The Whaley Law Firm as the sender. The communications were labeled as external, and the chain contained standard external-email warnings and disclaimers regarding confidentiality.

episodes.natural_language:
Case: Kimberly-Brasher-Premise-2-25-2023. Client: Kimberly Brasher. Re: CLAIM C321835845 – KIMBERLY BRASHER – DOL 2/25/23.

On October 9, 2023, in the matter of claim C321835845 for Kimberly Brasher, with date of loss 2/25/2023, Sarena M. Tuttle, a Litigation Paralegal and Workers’ Compensation Case Manager for The Whaley Law Firm, sent an email to Tatisha Booker of Sedgwick Claims. The message was also copied to Jessa Galosmo and Aaron Whaley. Sarena acknowledged receipt of the claim information and informed Tatisha that she had forwarded the information to Jessa Galosmo, who would serve as the case manager and the main point of contact at this phase of the claim. Sarena stated that Jessa would provide the requested information as soon as possible, and she invited Tatisha to contact them directly with any questions. The email included Sarena’s signature with her title and firm, The Whaley Law Firm, 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222; direct line 502-357-9971; office line 502-583-4022 ext 104; email Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com, and a note indicating a new email address.

Tatisha Booker, a Sedgwick Claims Examiner handling Zurich American Insurance Company matters, replied on the same day, October 9, 2023, at about 11:48 a.m. She identified herself as Tish Booker, ACLA, LPCS, and provided her direct line (847-405-1082), email (Tatisha.Booker@sedgwick.com), and fax (847-405-1040). Her email also referenced Sedgwick’s website (www.sedgwick.com) and included the tagline Caring counts®. She identified the carrier as Zurich American Insurance Company and noted Sedgwick Claims Management Services, Inc., with California license number 2731012. For urgent matters, she directed contact to her manager, Dandre Lewis-Yhap, at 972-372-6135 or dandre.lewisyhap@sedgwick.com.

The message also contained standard privacy and confidentiality language indicating that any personal data processed by Sedgwick will be handled in accordance with applicable data protection laws. It stated that communications and any attachments are confidential and intended solely for the recipient, and if the message was received in error, the recipient should not copy, distribute, or disclose its contents, should notify the sender, and delete the message from their system.

episodes.original_body:
Case: Kimberly-Brasher-Premise-2-25-2023
Client: Kimberly Brasher

__CLIENT CONTACT__
__Details:__ Recvd JG note - Client Texted in for an update - Advised JG to let Client know to call office instead moving forward - Called Client - Discussed Litigation Process - Updated her that both Defs have been served & have until roughly April 5, 2024 to Answer the Complaint - Discuss Written Discovery Phase & Advised we will send a packet of questions to her upon receipt & to call us when she receives them to go over them in detail - Client Expressed understanding & appreciated the update & information 
__Person Making Contact:__ Sarena
__Date & Time__: March 08 2024
episodes.natural_language:
Case: Kimberly-Brasher-Premise-2-25-2023. On March 08, 2024, initial client contact was made with Kimberly Brasher regarding the case, with Sarena as the person making contact.

The client had texted in for an update after receiving a JG note. I advised JG to inform the client to call the office moving forward rather than texting. I then called the client and discussed the litigation process, updating her that both defendants have been served and have until roughly April 5, 2024 to answer the complaint. We discussed the written discovery phase and I advised that we will send a packet of questions to her upon receipt and that she should call us when she receives them so we can go over them in detail. The client expressed understanding and appreciated the update and information.

episodes.natural_language:
This note concerns the case of Kimberly Brasher v. Networks USA XIV, Inc., et al., with the client identified as Kimberly Brasher and the file labeled Kimberly-Brasher-Premise-2-25-2023. The communications revolve around whether Walgreens should be added as a defendant in the matter and how to handle potential liability of the previously named defendants.

On May 16, 2024, Aaron Whaley of Whaley Law Firm sent an email to Lee E. Sitlinger of Sitlinger & Theiler and to Kimberly Brasher’s Filevine project email address. In the body of the message, Whaley said, “Lee, see the attached letter I received from Sedgwick regarding Walgreens. It seems as if they are maintaining that they are not responsible. I think the Agreed Order would just be to add Walgreen's as a defendant.” The message was dated Thursday, May 16, 2024, at 12:39:36 -0400. The note includes Whaley’s contact information at the Whaley Law Firm (712 Lyndon Ln, Louisville, KY 40222; 502-583-4022) and the various recipients’ contact details.

Earlier in the chain, on April 24, 2024, Lee Sitlinger replied to the matter, writing, “Sounds good. I’ll send over a proposed order for your review and approval.” This response is recorded in the email thread with the header showing Sitlinger’s law firm at 320 Whittington Parkway, Suite 304, Louisville, KY 40222, and his contact information (lsitlinger@sitlingerlaw.com; 502-589-2627 x 703; 502-583-3415 fax).

Also on April 24, 2024, at 1:11 PM, Aaron Whaley sent an email to Sharon Archer with copies to Lee Sitlinger, Bryce Koon, and Kimberly Brasher’s Filevine project address regarding the same case. In his message, Whaley stated that he was “fine with doing an Agreed Order substituting in Walgreens so long as if evidence comes out showing the removed defendants have liability we can add them back. I just want to make sure Walgreens does not point the finger against an empty chair. Thanks.”

Earlier that same day, at approximately 12:59 PM, Sharon Archer, Legal Assistant to Lee E. Sitlinger, wrote to counsel: “Dear Counsel: Attached is a copy of Attorney Lee Sitlinger’s correspondence regarding the above-referenced matter. If you have any questions or problem(s) opening the attachment, please do not hesitate to contact our office. Thank you.” Archer provided her contact details for SITLINGER LAW—320 Whittington Parkway, Suite 304, Louisville, Kentucky 40222; sarcher@sitlingerlaw.com; Telephone (502) 589-2627 x 708; Facsimile (502) 583-3415.

The exchange concludes with the repeated note from Whaley on May 16, 2024, referencing the Sedgwick letter and the notion that Walgreens should be added as a defendant if the Sedgwick position persists, thereby aligning with the possibility of an Agreed Order substituting Walgreens for the time being.

The communication indicated that Walgreens’ firm represents Walgreen Co. in the matter.

Later that same morning, at 10:15 a.m., Sarena replied: Good morning Sharon, and thank you for the email. She asked whether there were any dates available in September and provided her own contact details: The Whaley Law Firm, 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222; D: (502) 357-9971; O: (502) 583-4022 ext 104; E: Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com, with a note to please use the new email address.

The email thread continued with a message from Sharon Archer sent around 2:53 p.m. that same day. She stated: “Sarena: No, I’m sorry, Mr. Sitlinger wants to start with October dates. Thank you.” Sharon signed as the Legal Assistant to Lee E. Sitlinger of Sitlinger Law, providing the office address at 320 Whittington Parkway, Suite 304, Louisville, Kentucky 40222; her email sarcher@sitlingerlaw.com; and her direct line, telephone (502) 589-2627 x 708; facsimile (502) 583-3415.

In the matter of Kimberly Brasher v. Walgreens Co., et al., McClean Circuit Court, No. 24-CI-00012, the client Kimberly Brasher is represented by The Whaley Law Firm. On July 16, 2024, Sarena M. Tuttle, a Litigation Paralegal and Workers’ Compensation Case Manager at The Whaley Law Firm, conveyed a scheduling question to Sharon K. Archer, the Legal Assistant to Lee E. Sitlinger at Sitlinger Law. Tuttle noted that, although they would prefer not to push the claim far into the future, they would likely want to schedule deposition of the Walgreens Representatives who oversaw the property and its maintenance for the same day as Kimberly Brasher’s deposition, and asked for dates when both offices would be available. Tuttle’s signature included her contact information: The Whaley Law Firm, 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222; D: (502) 357-9971; O: (502) 583-4022 ext 104; E: Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com, with a note that this is her new email address.

Earlier that morning, at 9:57 AM, Sharon Archer informed Sarena that her firm represents Walgreens Co. in the above-referenced matter and that Mr. Sitlinger would like to schedule Kimberly Brasher’s deposition sometime in October at Walgreens’ office, requesting as soon as possible to provide Mr. Whaley’s or Mr. Koon’s availability in October 2024, with the exception of October 16–25. Archer provided Sitlinger Law’s contact details: 320 Whittington Parkway, Suite 304, Louisville, KY 40222; sarcher@sitlingerlaw.com; Telephone (502) 589-2627 x 708; Facsimile (502) 583-3415.

Earlier still, in Archer’s note, there is a response indicating a preference for October dates, with a clarification that Sitlinger would like to begin with October rather than September. At 10:53 AM, Archer wrote back: “No, I’m sorry, Mr. Sitlinger wants to start with October dates. Thank you.” This was followed by Archer reiterating Walgreens’ position that the deposition of Ms. Brasher be scheduled in October in Walgreens’ office, and asking for the availability of Whaley’s or Koon’s schedules in October 2024 to take Ms. Brasher’s deposition, specifically excluding October 16–25.

Finally, at 11:51:10 AM on July 16, 2024, Sarena responded with a plan: while they would prefer not to push the claim too far into the future, they would likely want to schedule the Walgreens Representatives’ deposition for the same day as Ms. Brasher’s deposition. She requested that Archer provide dates on which both Sitlinger Law and Walgreens’ Representative would be available. This message also reiterated Sarena’s contact details and noted her new email address.

The sequence begins with Sharon Archer, Legal Assistant to Lee E. Sitlinger of Sitlinger Law, writing from sarcher@sitlingerlaw.com to Sarena Tuttle, Litigation Paralegal and Workers’ Compensation Case Manager at The Whaley Law Firm (sarena@whaleylawfirm.com). In her message, Sharon notes that she has forwarded Sarena’s email to Mr. Sitlinger, who is currently out of the office, and states that they will have to get back to Sarena regarding her email. The message is dated July 16, 2024 at 16:10:30 +0000. Sharon’s signature indicates she is with Sitlinger Law, located at 320 Whittington Parkway, Suite 304, Louisville, Kentucky 40222, and provides her contact details: sarcher@sitlingerlaw.com, telephone (502) 589-2627 x 708, and facsimile (502) 583-3415.

Earlier in the day, Sarena Tuttle had sent a message (dated July 16, 2024) in which she stated that, while they would prefer not to push the claim far into the future, they would likely want to schedule the deposition of Walgreens Representatives who oversaw the property and its maintenance for the same day as the deposition of Kimberly Brasher. She requested dates on which both Sharon’s office and the Walgreens Representative would be available.

The chain shows an earlier reply from Sharon Archer, sent at 9:57? AM, in which she confirms that Walgreens Co. represents the defendant in the matter and states that Mr. Sitlinger would like to schedule the deposition of Kimberly Brasher for some time in October in Sitlinger’s office. Sharon asks for availability in October 2024 for Mr. Whaley or Mr. Koon to take Ms. Brasher’s deposition, with the exception of October 16–25. Her message includes her full signature with contact information and the firm’s address: SITLINGER LAW, 320 Whittington Parkway, Suite 304, Louisville, Kentucky 40222; sarcher@sitlingerlaw.com; telephone (502) 589-2627 x 708; facsimile (502) 583-3415.

A follow-up from Sarena at 10:15 AM asks Sharon if there are any dates in September, expressing openness to scheduling in that month.

Sharon replies at 10:53? AM, clarifying that Mr. Sitlinger prefers to start with October dates.

The thread then returns to Sarena at 11:51 AM, noting that although they would rather not push the claim far into the future, they will likely want to schedule the deposition of the Walgreens Representatives (who oversaw the property and its maintenance) for the same day as Ms. Brasher’s deposition, and asking Sharon to provide dates on which both The Whaley Law Firm and the Walgreens Representative would be available.

In sum, the parties are coordinating deposition dates for Kimberly Brasher and for Walgreens Representatives (the representatives who oversaw the property and its maintenance), with October 2024 identified by Mr. Sitlinger as the starting window, subject to availability and an exception for October 16–25. The record captures multiple rolling attempts to align schedules, including requests for September options, and a note that Sharon forwarded Sarena’s email to Mr. Sitlinger, who is temporarily out of the office and would respond when available.

episodes.natural_language:
Case: Kimberly-Brasher-Premise-2-25-2023. Client: Kimberly Brasher. This matter concerns Kimberly Brasher v. Walgreen Co., et al., in McLean Circuit Court, No. 24-CI-00012.

In a July 22, 2024 email, Sarena M. Tuttle, Litigation Paralegal and Workers’ Compensation Case Manager at The Whaley Law Firm, addressed Sharon Archer and Curt Sitlinger (with Greg Whaley and Bryce Koon copied) regarding depositions in the Walgreens litigation. She thanked them for locating the best person to represent Walgreens for a deposition and requested an update once that representation is identified. She advised that Mr. Koon is available to schedule the deposition of Mrs. Brasher and noted that their October calendar is fairly open; she asked Walgreens to provide dates their office is available so they could discuss those dates with Ms. Brasher promptly. Her signature included The Whaley Law Firm’s contact information, including the new email address Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com.

The email chain also shows the ongoing scheduling discussion from July 16, 2024. Early that morning, Sharon Archer of Sitlinger Law informed Sarena that Walgreens represents Walgreens in the matter and that Mr. Sitlinger would like to schedule the deposition of Kimberly Brasher for sometime in October at Sitlinger’s office, requesting availability in October 2024 for Brasher’s deposition, with the exclusion of October 16–25. Sarena replied that, while they preferred not to push the claim far into the future, they would likely want to schedule the Walgreens representatives—who oversaw the property and its maintenance—to be deposed on the same day as Brasher, and she asked for dates when both offices could be available.

Sharon then clarified that Sitlinger wished to begin with October dates, rather than September. She asked for Mr. Whaley’s or Mr. Koon’s availability in October 2024 to depose Ms. Brasher, with the exception of Oct. 16–25. In response, Sarena reiterated the request for October dates and, when appropriate, September dates as well. She provided her contact details and reiterated the preference to schedule the deposition on October dates.

The thread continued with a brief exchange indicating Sharon would forward the message to Mr. Sitlinger, who was out of the office, and that they would have to get back to Whaley Law regarding the email. Sarena thanked Sharon for the update. The correspondence reflects the parties’ efforts to coordinate the deposition of Kimberly Brasher and the Walgreens representatives on the same day, with October 2024 identified as the initial target window and October 16–25 excluding, along with a request for mutual availability.

episodes.natural_language:
In the matter of Kimberly Brasher v. Walgreen Co., et al. (McLean Circuit Court, No. 24-CI-00012), the scheduling of Ms. Kimberly Brasher’s deposition became the subject of a series of emails between counsel for Walgreens and counsel for the plaintiff, starting in mid-July 2024. On July 16, 2024, Sharon K. Archer, the legal assistant to Lee E. Sitlinger at Sitlinger Law, informed Sarena Tuttle of The Whaley Law Firm that Walgreens’ litigation team would like to schedule Ms. Brasher’s deposition for October in their office, requesting availability for any October dates other than October 16–25. Archer identified the matter as representing Walgreen Co. and provided contact details for her firm: Sitlinger Law, 320 Whittington Parkway, Suite 304, Louisville, Kentucky 40222; sarcher@sitlingerlaw.com; telephone 502-589-2627 x708; fax 502-583-3415.

Also on July 16, Sarena Tuttle replied seeking dates in September as a possibility and noting Walgreens’ preference to schedule for October, with the understanding that Sitlinger’s firm would provide availability for October 2024 to take Ms. Brasher’s deposition at their office, excluding Oct. 16–25. In the interim, she suggested coordinating with Walgreens’ representatives who oversaw the property and its maintenance to possibly appear on the same deposition date. Sharon Archer responded that she had forwarded the email to Mr. Sitlinger, who was currently out of the office, and that they would respond when he returned.

Later that same day, July 16, Sarena acknowledged Sharon’s update with a brief “Awesome. Thank you so much.” The email correspondence continued over the next several days, with Sharon explaining that Mr. Sitlinger would prefer to begin with October dates, and Sarena asking for the availability of Mr. Whaley or Mr. Koon in October 2024 to take Ms. Brasher’s deposition, noting the dates to avoid were October 16–25. The thread shows ongoing back-and-forth while Sitlinger was out of the office, and Sarena indicating a desire to align dates for Ms. Brasher’s deposition along with any Walgreens representatives’ deposition on the same day, if possible.

On July 22, 2024, Sarena sent a message reiterating appreciation for locating the appropriate Walgreens representative to handle the deposition and requesting an update once the information was obtained. She indicated that Mr. Bryce Koon of The Whaley Law Firm was happy to schedule the deposition of Ms. Brasher, and pointed out that October calendars were fairly open. She asked that Walgreens’ office provide dates they were available so she could discuss them with Ms. Brasher as soon as possible. The message was copied to relevant parties, including Greg Whaley and Bryce Koon.

Finally, on July 23, 2024, Sharon Archer responded with a list of October dates that were available for Ms. Brasher’s deposition: October 1, 4, 7, 8, 9, 10, 11, 14, 15, and 16. Archer asked to advise whether any of those dates would work for Walgreens’ office. Archer signed as the Legal Assistant to Lee E. Sitlinger of Sitlinger Law, providing her office’s contact information and address: SITLINGER LAW, 320 Whittington Parkway, Suite 304, Louisville, Kentucky 40222; sarcher@sitlingerlaw.com; telephone 502-589-2627 x708; fax 502-583-3415. The message also lists the case details and indicates that the matter involves Walgreens Co., with depositions to be scheduled at the Sitlinger Law office, and references the deposition of the Walgreens representatives who oversaw the property and its maintenance. The exchange reflects ongoing coordination among The Whaley Law Firm (Sarena Tuttle, Curt Sitlinger, Greg Whaley, Bryce Koon) and Sitlinger Law (Sharon Archer) regarding timing and participants for the depositions in October.

In the matter of Kimberly Brasher v. Walgreens Co., McLean Circuit Court No. 24-CI-00012, the parties began coordinating the deposition schedule for Ms. Kimberly Brasher and, if needed, Walgreens’ representative who oversaw the property and its maintenance. The exchange involved Sarena M. Tuttle, litigation paralegal and workers’ compensation case manager for The Whaley Law Firm, and Sharon K. Archer, legal assistant to Lee E. Sitlinger at Sitlinger Law, with Curt Sitlinger and Greg Whaley also copied on the thread.

The planning kicked off on July 16, 2024, when Sharon Archer informed Sarena that Walgreens would like to schedule the deposition for October, to be held in Walgreens’ office, and asked for Whaley’s availability in October, noting that availability should exclude October 16 through 25. A few minutes later, Sarena requested dates in September as well, but Sharon clarified that the start should be in October and thanked her. Sarena then asked for both offices’ availability in October so they could coordinate with Ms. Brasher and, later that day, Sharon acknowledged she would forward the request to Mr. Sitlinger, who was out of the office at the time, and said they would need to get back with a response. Sarena wrapped up that exchange by simply noting she appreciated the update.

On July 22, 2024, Sarena wrote again to Sharon and Curt Sitlinger, expressing appreciation for locating the best Walgreens representative for a deposition and noting that Mr. Koon was happy to schedule the deposition of Mrs. Brasher. With October fairly open in their calendar, she asked that Walgreens provide dates your office was available so those dates could be discussed with Mrs. Brasher.

The following day, July 23, 2024, Sharon provided Walgreens’ available dates for Ms. Brasher’s deposition: October 1, 4, 7, 8, 9, 10, 11, 14, 15, and 16. She asked for confirmation on which of those dates would work. Later that day, Sarena responded: October 1 at 10:00 a.m. sounded good. She added that if a Walgreens representative could be determined, they could be added in the afternoon if needed, and she asked whether a Zoom deposition would be preferable given that Mrs. Brasher lives about 2.5 hours away and the Walgreens representative’s location was still undetermined.

Throughout, the correspondence circulated among the following participants and roles:
- Sarena M. Tuttle, litigation paralegal and workers’ compensation case manager for The Whaley Law Firm, Louisville, KY.
- Sharon K. Archer, legal assistant to Lee E. Sitlinger at Sitlinger Law, Louisville, KY.
- Curt Sitlinger, attorney at Sitlinger Law.
- Greg Whaley, attorney at The Whaley Law Firm.
- Bryce Koon, associated with The Whaley Law Firm.

All communications reference the case’s procedural posture and the practical considerations of scheduling: confirming October as the target month, identifying available dates for Ms. Brasher’s deposition at Walgreens’ office (and possibly coordinating with a Walgreens representative), and evaluating the option of conducting the deposition by Zoom due to distance and the yet-undetermined location of the Walgreens representative.

From: Sarena Tuttle [sarena@whaleylawfirm.com](mailto:sarena@whaleylawfirm.com)

Date: Mon, 16 Sep 2024 11:23:57 -0400

Good afternoon Kim,
 Please find attached the Discovery Requests from the Defense Counsel
in your premise liability claim. Please review the packet of questions and
simply give our office a call to go over them. We understand the packet can
seem overwhelming at first glance, however, we are here to assist in
completing this task.
 There will be several questions that you will not need to answer as
they are outside your scope of information, such as which 'experts' we will
call at trial. There are also requests for document production and we will
have most of these documents already in your file and you will not need to
produce them a 2nd time. Again, simply give us a call and we will discuss
these in further detail.

Sarena M. Tuttle
Litigation Paralegal &
Workers' Compensation Case Manager
The Whaley Law Firm
712 Lyndon Lane
Louisville, KY 40222
D: (502) 357-9971
O: (502) 583-4022 ext 104
E: Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com

episodes.natural_language:
Chronology of communications regarding Kimberly Brasher’s lien (case reference 20240514-001078) documents a short, three-message exchange between The Phia Group and The Whaley Law Firm in early October 2024.

On October 4, 2024, at approximately 10:06 AM, Sarah Bracken of The Phia Group emailed Sarena Tuttle regarding Kimberly Brasher. Sarah noted that it appeared dates of service were missing from the latest lien list because some items had been coded for “joint disorder” rather than being specific to the hip. She asked whether these dates should be added from Commonwealth Pain Associates and asked for confirmation on whether all such records should be included.

On October 9, 2024, at 1:38 PM, Sarena M. Tuttle, a Litigation Paralegal and Workers’ Compensation Case Manager at The Whaley Law Firm, replied. She apologized for the delayed response, explaining she had been out of the office at the end of the previous week. She confirmed that Sarah should include any and all records. She invited further questions or concerns to be discussed directly. Sarena provided her contact details: The Whaley Law Firm, 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222; D: (502) 357-9971; O: (502) 583-4022 ext 104; E: Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com, noting it as her new email address.

That same message contains the standard informational and confidentiality disclaimers typical of the correspondence. The notices make clear that the information is informational only, not a substitute for legal counsel, does not create an attorney-client relationship, and is confidential and intended only for the addressed entity. The Phia Group emphasizes that it is not a law firm and is not responsible for any claims coverage decisions or payment. The notices reiterate the need to seek licensed legal counsel and advise deletion if received in error. Similar language appears again in later notes.

On October 10, 2024, at 17:43:24 UTC, Sarah Bracken sent a follow-up email to Sarena. She stated that it may be easier to include the dates of service missing from the lien. Her closing included her full signature information: Senior Recovery Specialist, The Phia Group, LLC; Phone/Fax: 502-213-5734; LinkedIn follow prompt. The email also provided two payment addresses that appeared in the thread, and a request to include the case number with payments: "PAYMENTS SHOULD BE MAILED TO, P.O. BOX 499, CANTON, MA 02021" (in this message) along with the case number. The message again referenced her manager, Jamie Johnson (JJohnson@phiagroup.com), and stated that both she and Jamie value the recipient’s feedback. Her signature line also included the standard business disclaimers that accompany the correspondence.

Additionally, the thread contains several embedded image references (cid:image001.png, cid:image002.png, cid:image003.png) associated with the October 10 message, indicating the presence of attached visuals in that email.

Throughout the correspondence, references appear to the same subject line: "Kimberly Brasher (20240514-001078" and/or "Re: Kimberly Brasher (20240514-001078." The communication trail also includes an earlier note about where payments should be mailed (P.O. Box 390, Canton, MA 02021) in the October 4 message, contrasted with the later instruction to mail payments to P.O. Box 499, Canton, MA 02021. The Phia Group’s branding elements, including “Follow Us On LinkedIn!” and the manager contact, Jamie Johnson, recur in the signatures.

In summary, the exchange shows a collaborative effort to ensure all relevant dates of service are captured for the lien, with The Whaley Law Firm requesting that all records be included, and The Phia Group seeking confirmation and offering guidance on where to send payment and whom to contact for feedback. The chain also includes multiple standard confidentiality and informational-use disclaimers and indicates a change in Sarena Tuttle’s listed email address to Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com.

Case: Kimberly-Brasher-Premise-2-25-2023. Client: Kimberly Brasher. The matter titled “Re: Kimberly Brasher (20240514-001078)” centers on communications between The Whaley Law Firm and The Phia Group regarding Kimberly Brasher’s claim. The exchange includes the following participants and details.

On October 4, 2024, Sarah Bracken of The Phia Group wrote in a message beginning Good morning. She stated that she had received a voicemail about Kimberly Brasher and indicated that some dates of service were not included in the latest lien list because they had been coded for joint disorder rather than hip-specific. She asked whether those dates should all be added from Commonwealth Pain Associates and closed with her signature, which included her title as Senior Recovery Specialist, The Phia Group, LLC, payment mailing address (P.O. Box 390, Canton, MA 02021), and a note that her manager Jamie Johnson (JJohnson@phiagroup.com) and she valued feedback. 

On October 9, 2024 at 1:38 PM, Sarena M. Tuttle, a Litigation Paralegal and Workers’ Compensation Case Manager at The Whaley Law Firm (712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222; D: 502-357-9971; O: 502-583-4022 ext 104; E: Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com; please note the new email address), responded with an apology for the delayed reply due to being out of the office at the end of the prior week. She confirmed that the recipient should include any and all records they may have and invited them to contact Whaley Law Firm directly to discuss any questions or concerns. 

The next message, sent October 10, 2024 at approximately 1:43 PM by Sarah Bracken, reiterated her earlier point and suggested it would be easier to include the dates of service missing from the lien. Her signature noted her role as Senior Recovery Specialist at The Phia Group, LLC, with the same contact and payment mailing details as before, and she added that her manager Jamie Johnson (JJohnson@phiagroup.com) valued the recipient’s feedback.

Later that same day, October 10, 2024 at 1:57 PM, Sarena Tuttle sent another message to Sarah Bracken. In this note, she asked Sarah to refer to their original correspondence dated October 1, 2024 (which was attached) in which Whaley outlined in detail what they believed was missing and provided a complete treatment summary for reference and comparison. She again provided her contact information and emphasized the new email address for future correspondence.

The thread also contains the standard informational and confidentiality disclaimers typically included by The Phia Group. These placeholders indicate that the information is for informational purposes only, not a substitute for legal counsel, does not create an attorney–client relationship, and is confidential or privileged. They remind recipients to contact the sender if the message is received in error and to delete it. The notices appear repeatedly in the chain, alongside the line stating that The Phia Group is not a law firm and is not responsible for claims decisions or payment unless explicitly stated.

In summary, the exchange documents a back-and-forth about missing dates of service and the need to augment the lien with hip-specific records, references to records from Commonwealth Pain Associates, and the inclusion of a complete treatment summary. It also notes the existence of an attached October 1, 2024 correspondence detailing what was missing and a complete treatment summary, and it confirms the communications and contact details among Kimberly Brasher’s representatives, The Whaley Law Firm, and The Phia Group, including the updated email address for Sarena Tuttle.

episodes.natural_language:
Case: Kimberly-Brasher-Premise-2-25-2023; Client: Kimberly Brasher. The matter at hand concerns the file identified as Kimberly Brasher (20240514-001078). The exchange takes place in October 2024 between The Whaley Law Firm and The Phia Group, with the subject line referencing the Kimberly Brasher case.

On October 11, 2024, Sarena M. Tuttle, a Litigation Paralegal and Workers’ Compensation Case Manager at The Whaley Law Firm, sent an email to Sarah Bracken of The Phia Group. In her message, Tuttle said, “Good morning Sarah, this is perfectly fine. Enjoy your vacation next week!” and she signed with her full contact information, noting a new email address: Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com. The Whaley Law Firm’s address is 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222, with a direct line of 502-357-9971 and the office line 502-583-4022 ext 104. The message included the standard confidentiality notice and other routine email footers, and it referenced that the new email address should be noted.

Earlier that same day, Sarah Bracken replied from The Phia Group. She stated that she would have their claims department review to add all the claims and would discuss the matter once those claims were received; she would be out of the office the following week and would respond after returning. Bracken’s signature identified her as Senior Recovery Specialist at The Phia Group, with the same phone and fax number (502-213-5734) and a note to follow The Phia Group on LinkedIn. The email also contained a line instructing that payments should be mailed to P.O. Box 499, Canton, MA 02021 and should include the case number, and it included a reminder that her manager, Jamie Johnson (JJohnson@phiagroup.com), and Bracken value feedback. The same message contained the long standard disclaimers about the informational nature of the communication and the absence of an attorney-client relationship.

The thread shows earlier correspondence from October 10, 2024, in which Sarena Tuttle sent a message to Sarah Bracken (cc’ing Bryce Koon) stating, “Please see our original correspondence to you on 10.01.2024 (attached) where we outlined in detail what we believe to be missing as well as a complete treatment summary for you to reference & compare.” Tuttle again provided her contact information and reiterated the new email address. The message also included the familiar confidentiality and legal disclaimers.

On October 10, 2024, earlier in the day, Bracken had written: “Hello, It may be easier if you include the dates of service you are missing from the lien.” This note was followed by Bracken’s standard signature block and the reminder about mailing payments to Canton, MA, with the case number included.

On October 9, 2024, at 1:38 PM, Tuttle replied to Bracken. In that message, she apologized for the delayed response due to being out of the office at the end of the prior week. She asked Bracken to include any and all records Bracken might have and invited further questions or concerns, offering to discuss them in more detail. This message carried Tuttle’s full Whaley Law Firm signature and the same confidentiality disclaimers.

On October 4, 2024, Bracken had written: Good morning. She reported receiving Tuttle’s voicemail regarding Kimberly Brasher and explained that there were dates of service not included in the latest list because they were coded for a joint disorder rather than being specific to the hip. Bracken asked whether these dates should be added from Commonwealth Pain Associates. Her message again included her standard signature and the usual disclaimers.

Throughout the chain, the Emails included the Phia Group’s and Whaley Law Firm’s standard disclaimers about confidentiality, the informational nature of the communication, and the absence of an attorney-client relationship. Notably, the chain shows two different mailing addresses for payments: P.O. Box 499, Canton, MA 02021 (as stated by Sarah Bracken on October 11) and P.O. Box 390, Canton, MA 02021 (as stated by Bracken in Bracken’s October 4 message). It also shows a cc’d party, Bryce Koon, in the October 10 exchange. The case number consistently tied to the thread is 20240514-001078. The communications reflect that there were missing records and a complete treatment summary provided by The Whaley Law Firm in their October 1, 2024 correspondence (referenced in the October 10 message as attached). The thread also notes that the claims department at The Phia Group would review to add all the claims and that the parties would reconvene on the matter after those records were received, with Bracken out of the office for the following week.

From: Bryce Koon [bryce@whaleylawfirm.com](mailto:bryce@whaleylawfirm.com)
To: Lee Sitlinger [lsitlinger@sitlingerlaw.com](mailto:lsitlinger@sitlingerlaw.com)
Cc: Kimberly Brasher Premise 2/25/2023 - Filevine Project Email Address [KimberlyBrasherSFZ3954564@louisvilleaccidentlawyer.filevineapp.com](mailto:KimberlyBrasherSFZ3954564@louisvilleaccidentlawyer.filevineapp.com), Sarena Tuttle [sarena@whaleylawfirm.com](mailto:sarena@whaleylawfirm.com)
Date: Mon Oct 14 2024 11:16:19 GMT-04:00

Good afternoon counsel,

Please see the attached documents discussed during Ms. Brasher's
deposition.

I would also like to follow up on the discovery requests we served to
Walgreens, as well as request some dates for a corporate rep deposition for
your client.

Finally, our office sent over a demand a while back, have you had any
opportunity to review it? If you and your client are interested in
attempting mediation in lieu of further litigation and informal
negotiations, we could try and get something on the books.

Sorry for throwing all of that at you, just figured I'd knock it all out
with one email!

Thank you,
*W. Bryce Koon, Esq.*
The Whaley Law Firm
712 Lyndon Lane
Louisville, KY 40222
Phone: (502) 365-5043
Fax: (502) 237-3207

you should not use the information contained herein or forward it to any
third person not intended to receive it. *

episodes.natural_language:
Case: Kimberly-Brasher-Premise-2-25-2023. Client: Kimberly Brasher. This note records communications related to the defense counsel’s discovery requests in Kimberly Brasher’s premise liability claim against Walgreens.

The most recent message, dated November 23, 2024 at 10:59:44 a.m. Central Time, was sent from Kimberly Brasher (kimberbrasher73@gmail.com) to Sarena Tuttle of The Whaley Law Firm, with the subject line “Re: The Defense Counsel's Discovery Requests.” In her email, Kimberly wrote: “Hi Serena. This is my second attempt to reach out for any information on my case before I just let all of WKy and southern IN sue me. Thanks.” She signed the message “Kimberly K Brasher.”

Prior to that, on November 8, 2024 at approximately 9:17 a.m., Kimberly Brasher wrote to Sarena Tuttle asking: “Hi Sarena-Just reaching out to inquire if there has been any update or recent movement in any direction on my Walgreens case. Thank you-” This message was also from Kimberly K. Brasher.

Earlier, on September 16, 2024 at about 10:24 a.m., Sarena Tuttle replied to Kim. Her message stated: “Good afternoon Kim, Please find attached the Discovery Requests from the Defense Counsel in your premise liability claim. Please review the packet of questions and simply give our office a call to go over them. We understand the packet can seem overwhelming at first glance, however, we are here to assist in completing this task. There will be several questions that you will not need to answer as they are outside your scope of information, such as which 'experts' we will call at trial. There are also requests for document production and we will have most of these documents already in your file and you will not need to produce them a 2nd time. Again, simply give us a call and we will discuss these in further detail.” The signature identified Sarena M. Tuttle as a Litigation Paralegal and Workers’ Compensation Case Manager at The Whaley Law Firm, located at 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222. Contact details listed were D: (502) 357-9971, O: (502) 583-4022 ext 104, E: Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com, with a note to “PLEASE NOTE NEW EMAIL ADDRESS.”

Thank you for your response. I wasn’t aware of anyone’s retirement, the defense counsel changing, or anything else that may be holding up the defendant’s response to my claim. I do expect the hospitals and other medical providers to put a garnishment on me any day now, which is why I have an urgent interest in finding out if we’re any closer to a settlement or lack thereof. I’m not in regular contact with your office, so please give me some grace if I sound pushy-I started my claim a year or better ago, and was not aware this would be such a lengthy process or endeavor. Thank you.

Reply to Client:
Good morning Kim,
 I can definitely understand your frustration with the process, I greatly apologize that you were not better informed as to how long litigation typically takes. On a standard Circuit Court Case can take 2 years easily, without any snags or delays. Your claim however is right on track with that timeline. The Defense did make a speedy change and we do not anticipate a huge delay for the new counsel to catch up. We anticipate scheduling Mediation in the Spring, if the Defense is not open to settlement discussion once they are caught up. If you are being contacted by medical providers related to this claim, please advise them that the bills are in a pending litigation and feel free to provide our contact information to anyone attempting to collect them, please do not let them go into collections or cause any further issues for yourself. We are here to help you with those. If you have any other questions, please do not hesitate to contact us to discuss them in further detail. 
__Person Making Contact:__ Sarena
__Date & Time__: November 26 2024

The client had sent an email explaining that she was not aware of anyone’s retirement, the defense counsel changing, or any other factor that might be delaying the defendant’s response to her claim. She stated that she expects hospitals and other medical providers to place a garnishment on her almost immediately, which created an urgent need to know whether a settlement is closer or no settlement is anticipated. She noted that she is not in regular contact with the office and asked for some leeway if she sounded pushy, since she began her claim more than a year ago and did not anticipate such a lengthy process.

Reply to Client: Sarena replied to Kim with empathy and clarity. She acknowledged Kim’s frustration with the process and apologized for not keeping her better informed about how long litigation typically takes. She explained that a standard circuit court case can take about two years easily, absent snags or delays, and that Kim’s claim is currently on track with that general timeline. She noted that the defense had made a rapid change and that they do not anticipate a significant delay for the new counsel to get up to speed. Mediation was anticipated to be scheduled in the spring, provided the defense does not remain closed to settlement discussions once they are caught up. Regarding bills from medical providers, Kim was advised to inform them that the bills are in a pending litigation and to feel free to share the firm’s contact information with anyone attempting to collect them; she was cautioned not to let the bills go into collections or create further issues for herself, and the firm pledged to help with those matters. The message closed with an invitation for Kim to reach out with any additional questions or to discuss them in more detail.

episodes.natural_language:
Case: Kimberly-Brasher-Premise-2-25-2023. Client: Kimberly Brasher. The note tracks an email chain about discovery requests from the defense counsel in Kimberly Brasher’s premise liability claim, with the subject line The Defense Counsel's Discovery Requests.

On November 27, 2024, Kimberly Brasher sent an email to Sarena Tuttle of The Whaley Law Firm, with Bryce Koon copied, replying, “Thank you for the update. That is very helpful.”

In the prior day’s correspondence, November 26, 2024, Sarena M. Tuttle, a Litigation Paralegal and Workers’ Compensation Case Manager at The Whaley Law Firm, wrote to Kim explaining that she could understand Kim’s frustration with the process and apologizing for not having been better informed about how long litigation typically takes. She noted that a standard circuit court case can take two years or more, without snags or delays, and that Kim’s claim is on track with that timeline. She also mentioned that the defense had recently changed counsel and that they did not anticipate a significant delay for the new counsel to catch up. Mediation was anticipated in the Spring if the defense was open to settlement after they were caught up. Sarena advised Kim to inform medical providers who contact her that the bills are in pending litigation and to feel free to provide The Whaley Law Firm’s contact information to anyone attempting to collect them, to avoid garnishment or further issues. She reassured Kim that the firm could assist with those matters and invited any further questions. The message included Sarena’s signature block with her title, the firm’s name and address at 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222, and contact details: D: (502) 357-9971, O: (502) 583-4022 ext 104, E: Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com, with a note indicating a NEW EMAIL ADDRESS.

Earlier, on November 25, 2024, at 3:56 PM, Kimberly Brasher wrote expressing that she was not aware of anyone’s retirement or the defense counsel changing, or anything else affecting the defendant’s response to her claim. She stated she expected hospitals and other medical providers to garnish her wages any day and emphasized an urgent interest in finding out whether there was progress toward settlement or not. She apologized for sounding pushy, explaining that she had started her claim over a year ago and was not expecting such a lengthy process.

That same day, at 8:41 AM, Sarena Tuttle replied to Kim, asking Kim to explain her previous statement and asking, “Who is suing you?” She noted that Kim’s deposition had been taken on October 1, 2024. She explained that the defense counsel had recently changed due to Mr. Sitlinger’s retirement and that they did not anticipate any significant movement in Kim’s case until after the New Year. She emphasized the need to allow the new counsel time to review the case and that, once they were caught up, they hoped to schedule mediation. However, she added that whether mediation could occur would depend on the new counsel’s position, and that The Whaley Law Firm would reach out to discuss the next steps once they heard back from the new counsel.

On Saturday, November 23, 2024, at 11:59 AM, Kimberly Brasher wrote, “Hi Serena. This is my second attempt to reach out for any information on my case before I just let all of WKy and southern IN sue me. Thanks.” She signed, “Kimberly K Brasher.”

Prior messages include Kim’s earlier notes: on Friday, November 8, 2024, at 9:17 AM, she asked if there had been any update or recent movement regarding her Walgreens case. On Monday, September 16, 2024, at 10:24 AM, Sarena Tuttle sent a message attaching the Discovery Requests from the Defense Counsel in Kim’s premise liability claim. She urged Kim to review the packet and call to discuss. Sarena acknowledged the packet could seem overwhelming but offered assistance in completing the task. She noted that several questions would not require answers because they were outside Kim’s scope of information (such as which experts would be called at trial) and that there were requests for document production. She added that most documents would already be in Kim’s file and she would not need to produce them a second time. The message concluded with Sarena’s signature block, including her role, the firm’s address, and contact information, and a note reiterating the “PLEASE NOTE NEW EMAIL ADDRESS.”

The communications consistently reference a Walgreens-related premise liability claim, with discussions about discovery requests, anticipated timelines, changes in defense counsel due to retirement, and expectations regarding mediation and settlement, as well as guidance for managing medical bills during pending litigation. The email chain also notes The Whaley Law Firm’s contact details and a new email address for Sarena.

The matter concerns client Kimberly Brasher, referenced as Kimberly-Brasher-Premise-2-25-2023, with the case file designation 20240514-001078. On December 4, 2024, Sarena M. Tuttle, a litigation paralegal and workers’ compensation case manager at The Whaley Law Firm, sent an email to Sarah Ingle Hobbs of The Phia Group (cc’ing Bryce Koon) confirming receipt of information and noting that the two charges dated March 10 and March 12, both labeled “Unknown Provider,” for the amount of $17,270.50 each, appeared related. She asked for clarification on whether these charges are duplicative or if they reflect the same procedure performed at the beginning and again at the end of Mrs. Brasher’s inpatient treatment, given that she was hospitalized from March 10 through March 12. Tuttle also provided her contact details and indicated a new email address.

The email chain shows prior correspondence beginning November 26, 2024, when Sarah Ingle indicated she had taken over the handling of the file. She stated that she had removed all claims marked “claim watcher LLC” from the Whaley Law Firm’s listing and had requested additional information from her claims department for claims marked “Provider Unknown.” She promised to forward the updated lien as soon as she received a response. In a reply dated November 27, 2024, Sarena Tuttle thanked Sarah for the update, said she would update their contact information, and looked forward to hearing from her.

On December 3, 2024, Sarah Ingle emailed again, attaching the claim forms with additional provider information and asking Sarena to let her know if anything else was needed. Her message included her standard signature block with her role as Sr. Claim Recovery Specialist at The Phia Group, along with contact information (Phone: 502-213-5717; Fax: 502-213-5717) and a reminder to mail checks to P.O. Box 499, Canton, MA 02021.

In the December 4, 2024 message, Sarena acknowledged receipt and clarified the current issue: the two $17,270.50 charges on March 10 and March 12 from an “Unknown Provider” appeared related, but it remained to be determined whether they were duplicates or whether the same procedure occurred at the start and end of the inpatient stay for Mrs. Brasher, who was hospitalized March 10 through March 12. She reiterated that the charges were related information to be confirmed and included her contact details and new email address for future communications.

The correspondence thread also included the standard confidentiality and informational notices typical of Phia Group communications, which were repeated across the emails.

episodes.natural_language:
Case: Kimberly-Brasher-Premise-2-25-2023. The client is Kimberly Brasher. The correspondence centers on the file referenced as Kimberly Brasher (20240514-001078) and a lien related to Claim #22303927700, with an invoice described as an adjustment or repricing of one of her claims on a specific date of service (DOS).

 chronology of the emails:

- November 26, 2024. Sarah Ingle Hobbs of The Phia Group took over the handling of this file. She advised that she had removed all claims marked “claim watcher LLC” from The Phia Group’s listing and had requested additional information from the claims department for claims marked “Provider Unknown.” She stated that once responses were received she would forward the updated lien. She signed as a Senior Claim Recovery Specialist and included the standard check-mailing address for payments: Please mail all checks to P.O. Box 499, Canton, MA 02021.

- November 27, 2024. Sarena M. Tuttle of The Whaley Law Firm replied, thanking Sarah for the update and noting that she would update their contact information and look forward to further communication.

- December 3, 2024. Sarah Ingle sent an update with claim forms and additional provider information attached, asking Sarena to let her know if anything further was needed.

- December 4, 2024. Sarena responded that she had received the forms and that the information would be considered related. She noted, however, that there are two charges for 03/10 and 03/12 labeled “Unknown Provider” for the same amount, $17,270.50. She asked for confirmation whether these are duplicative or if they represent the same procedure performed at the beginning and again at the end of Mrs. Brasher’s inpatient treatment, given that she was hospitalized from 03/10 through 03/12.

- December 12, 2024. Sarah Ingle forwarded the client’s response regarding Claim #22303927700. She stated that 22303927700 is an invoice for repricing one of her claims on that DOS. The message notes the same check-mailing address (P.O. Box 499, Canton, MA 02021) and the standard closing from The Phia Group. The email includes the typical confidentiality and non-attorney relationship disclaimers that accompany these communications, indicating the information is for informational purposes only and not legal advice, and that The Phia Group is not a law firm.

Other details embedded in the thread:

- The Whaley Law Firm contact person is Sarena M. Tuttle, a Litigation Paralegal & Workers’ Compensation Case Manager, located at 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222. Her direct line is (502) 357-9971, and the office line is (502) 583-4022 ext. 104. Her email, updated in the thread, is Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com.

- The Phia Group contact is Sarah Ingle Hobbs, Senior Claim Recovery Specialist, The Phia Group, LLC, with a phone and fax number of (502) 213-5717. The mailing address for checks is the same P.O. Box in Canton, MA.

- The emails reference two specific claims: the internal file 20240514-001078 and Claim #22303927700. The DOS referenced in the December 12 correspondence is tied to the repricing invoice for that claim.

- The communications note ongoing work on provider information and lien status, including the handling of claims marked “Provider Unknown” and the removal of certain claims from listing, as well as the need to determine whether certain charges are duplicates.

- Throughout the thread, the standard disclosures accompany every message, reiterating that the information is informational only, not legal counsel, and that the Phia Group is not a law firm; any inadvertent use should be avoided and the information is confidential and limited to the intended recipient.

In summary, from late November to mid-December 2024, the Whaley Law Firm and The Phia Group coordinated on Kimberly Brasher’s file related to lien and claim 22303927700 (within the broader 20240514-001078 and the 2023 case Kimberly Brasher Premise). They addressed provider information, questioned two unknown-provider charges of $17,270.50 for 03/10 and 03/12 to determine if they were duplicates or a single procedure performed twice during Mrs. Brasher’s inpatient stay, and they exchanged invoices and updates regarding repricing on the date of service.

In the Kimberly Brasher matter (Case: Kimberly-Brasher-Premise-2-25-2023) for client Kimberly Brasher, the December 2024 email correspondence between The Whaley Law Firm and The Phia Group centers on lien accounting for claim 22303927700 and related charges tied to Kimberly Brasher’s inpatient treatment in March.

The exchange began with Sarah Ingle of The Phia Group noting, on November 26–27, 2024, that she had taken over the handling of the file and had removed all claims marked “claim watcher LLC” from the listing. She said she had requested additional information from her claims department for claims marked Provider Unknown and would forward the updated lien as soon as she received a response.

On December 3, 2024, Sarah sent the claim forms with additional provider information and asked Sarena Tuttle to let her know if anything else was needed. Sarena replied on December 4 that the received items would be considered related. However, she flagged that there were two charges dated 03/10 and 03/12 attributed to an “Unknown Provider” for the same amount of $17,270.50. She asked the Phia Group to confirm whether these charges are duplicative or whether they represent the same procedure performed at the beginning and end of Kimberly Brasher’s inpatient hospitalization, which lasted from March 10 through March 12.

Later on December 12, 2024, Sarah Ingle wrote back with the client’s response regarding Claim #22303927700, noting that 22303927700 is an invoice for repricing one of Brasher’s claims on that date. In a follow-up message, Sarena Tuttle confirmed her review of the figures: she saw 22303927700 billed at $17,270.50 with $1,727.50 paid, and 22302277800 also billed at $17,270.50 with $5,921.08 paid. Since the billed amounts match for both invoices, she asked for clarification on which provider ultimately paid and exactly how much was paid, or whether both invoices were paid, totaling $7,648.58. Sarena concluded by providing her contact details and requesting that the provider information be clarified to determine the total paid amount.

Steinberg, Co-Managing Partner at Quintairos, Prieto, Wood & Boyer, P.A. (McLean 24-CI-00012). The message included a security notice: “This is the first time you received an email from this sender (bryce@whaleylawfirm.com). Exercise caution when clicking links, opening attachments or taking further action, before validating its authenticity. Secured by Check Point.” In the body, Koon stated that he had learned Kimberly Brasher had been substituted as counsel in the matter and asked for any progress made on the discovery requests previously served on August 28, and when responses might be expected. He requested any available update and closed with his contact information for The Whaley Law Firm: 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222; phone 502-365-5043; fax 502-237-3207. The email also included the standard attorney-client privilege disclaimer.

Later on November 12, 2024, at approximately 1:40 p.m., Matthew B. Steinberg replied to Bryce Koon. Steinberg thanked Koon for the email and stated that he had just received the file and would likely need a few days to figure out what was going on. He asked if he could get back to Koon first thing next week, apologizing for the wait and promising to work as quickly as possible. Steinberg’s signature identified him as Co-Managing Partner of Quintairos, Prieto, Wood & Boyer, P.A., located at 444 East Main Street, Suite 201, Lexington, KY 40507. His phone number was listed as (859) 226-0057, with fax (859) 226-0059, and his email address matthew.steinberg@qpwblaw.com; the firm’s website and the section listing various U.S. jurisdictions appeared in the signature as well.

The email chain also includes the initial “From” line showing Bryce Koon’s November 12, 2024 message, which was sent from bryce@whaleylawfirm.com. In that message, Koon reaffirmed that he had been substituted as counsel in Kimberly Brasher v. Walgreens Co. and again asked whether there had been progress on the discovery requests previously served on August 28 or when responses could be expected. The message was sent from The Whaley Law Firm at 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222, and it listed the firm’s contact information: phone 502-365-5043, fax 502-237-3207. The email again carried the same standard privilege disclaimer, including the advisory about not forwarding the information to third parties and the instruction to contact The Whaley Law Firm if the message had been received in error.

Finally, on December 12, 2024, at 2:57:55 a.m. (GMT-05:00), Bryce Koon sent a follow-up to counsel regarding discovery in this matter. The subject line mirrored the case title, Kimberly Brasher v. Walgreens Co. (McLean 24-CI-00012). In the body, Koon wrote: “Good afternoon counsel, Just wanted to follow up on the discovery requests in this one. Any update appreciated.” The message was again cc’d to Kimberly Brasher’s Filevine project email address (KimberlyBrasherSFZ3954564@louisvilleaccidentlawyer.filevineapp.com). The email continued with the standard privilege disclaimer, reiterating that the electronic communication was intended only for the named recipient and cautioning recipients who might have received the message in error not to use or forward the information. The signature block identified W. Bryce Koon, Esq., of The Whaley Law Firm, with the same Louisville contact details previously listed.

In summary, the record shows three substantive communications among the parties in November and December 2024 concerning discovery in Kimberly Brasher v. Walgreens Co.: (1) an initial November 12 email from Bryce Koon asking for progress on discovery requests previously served on August 28 and when responses would be expected; (2) a November 12 reply from Matthew B. Steinberg indicating he had just received the file, would need a few days to assess the situation, and would follow up the following week; and (3) a December 12 follow-up from Bryce Koon requesting any update on the discovery requests. First, at 11:10 a.m. on November 12, 2024, W. Bryce Koon, Esq., of The Whaley Law Firm, sent an email to Matthew B. Steinberg, Esq., the Co-Managing Partner of Quintairos, Prieto, Wood & Boyer, P.A., with the subject Kimberly Brasher v. Walgreen Co. (McLean 24-CI-00012). Koon noted that counsel had been substituted on the case and asked whether there had been any progress on the discovery requests that had been served on August 28, or when responses might be expected. He requested any update in this regard. His message included his firm’s contact information: The Whaley Law Firm, 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222; phone (502) 365-5043; fax (502) 237-3207. The CC field also included Kimberly Brasher Premise 2/25/2023 - Filevine Project Email Address (KimberlyBrasherSFZ3954564@louisvilleaccidentlawyer.filevineapp.com). The email carried the standard attorney‑client privileged disclaimer stating it is intended only for the named recipient and advising that, if received in error, the sender should be contacted and that no privilege is waived by disclosure to the recipient. It also displayed a security notice indicating this was the first time the recipient had received an email from this sender and that the message was secured by Check Point.

Later that day, around 1:40 p.m., Matt Steinberg replied: “Thanks for the email and nice to meet you. I have just received the file and probably need a few days to figure out what is going on. Would you be okay if I got back to you first of next week. I see you have been waiting a bit and am sorry for that. I promise to work as quickly as possible.” Steinberg’s signature lists his title as Co-Managing Partner – Lexington Office, Quintairos, Prieto, Wood & Boyer, P.A., at 444 East Main Street, Suite 201, Lexington, KY 40507. The signature also includes the firm’s practice locations across numerous states, listed in full. The email, like the prior message, contained the standard attorney‑client privilege disclaimer. episodes.natural_language:
Case: Kimberly-Brasher-Premise-2-25-2023. Client: Kimberly Brasher. This record covers discovery communications in the case Kimberly Brasher v. Walgreen Co. (McLean 24-CI-00012).

Overview of the matter and parties’ counsel
The matter involves Kimberly Brasher as the client, with litigation against Walgreen Co. The correspondence spans several weeks in November and December 2024. The principal participants in these exchanges are W. Bryce Koon, Esq., of The Whaley Law Firm, representing Kimberly Brasher, and Matthew B. Steinberg, Esq., Co-Managing Partner of Quintairos, Prieto, Wood & Boyer, P.A., representing Walgreen Co. The Whaley Law Firm’s contact details are 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222, phone 502-365-5043, fax 502-237-3207. Quintairos’ Lexington Office is listed as 444 East Main Street, Suite 201, Lexington, KY 40507, with phone 859-226-0057 and fax 859-226-0059. Email addresses and a web presence for the firms are also noted in the correspondence. The messages include standard attorney-client privilege disclosures typical to electronic communications, stating the message is intended only for the named recipient and that any inadvertent receipt should be reported to the sending firm and not used or forwarded to others.

Chronology of discovery communications

- November 12, 2024. The first recorded email in the thread from this date shows Matthew B. Steinberg writing to Bryce Koon regarding progress on discovery. Steinberg notes that he has just received the file and will likely need a few days to understand what is happening, and asks if Bryce is okay with him responding by early next week, apologizing for any delay. The message contains Steinberg’s formal signature block and a standard privilege disclaimer.

- December 12, 2024. Bryce Koon follows up with Steinberg about the discovery requests in the case, asking for any updates. Bryce provides his firm’s contact details and reiterates the inquiry about the discovery progress. A standard privilege disclaimer is included in this and the other communications.

- December 13, 2024 (morning). Steinberg replies that they are working on the discovery and asks Bryce to forward any demand if one had been sent, as he cannot locate a demand in the file he received. His signature block is included with his contact information and firm branding. A prior header line shows a partial “From” and an “Error! Filename not specified.” note from the system.

- December 13, 2024 (later that morning). Bryce responds with a greeting, “Good morning Matthew,” and says, “Please see attached.” He provides a Dropbox link to relevant documents for the case: https://www.dropbox.com/scl/fi/tqrnzqyt94qf1ergchw4f/Brasher-Demand-Exhibits.pdf?rlkey=8lfk22d08o4z59ublt1q3ax6e&st=z9tiqqfc&dl=0. Bryce states that if there is trouble with the link or questions arise, he should be contacted. He includes his signature block and the standard privilege disclaimer. An image placeholder is noted as “Image removed by sender.” in the body of the message.

- December 23, 2024. Steinberg responds to the ongoing exchange, thanking the others and reporting that he has now gone through the file. He notes that “Lee had discovery complete and verified just before he transferred the file to me” and asks whether Lee ever served these responses on the other side. His message includes his signature block and the standard privilege disclaimer.

- December 27, 2024. Bryce Koon replies to Matthew Steinberg: “Good afternoon Matthew, We have not received any discovery responses that I am aware of.” He signs as W. Bryce Koon, Esq., The Whaley Law Firm, with the firm’s full address and contact numbers. The message includes the firm’s standard privilege disclaimer. The CC line for this message shows the ongoing referral of the Kimberly Brasher matter within the Filevine project and related project email address.

Additional case and submission context
The communications repeatedly reference discovery requests and the status of responses in the case. The subject line across the emails identifies the matter as “Kimberly Brasher v. Walgreen Co. (McLean 24-CI-00012).” The case is tracked under the header “Case: Kimberly-Brasher-Premise-2-25-2023” with the client listed as Kimberly Brasher. Several emails include or reference the Filevine project email address associated with Kimberly Brasher’s premise, which appears in the CC lines of multiple messages. The messages also show an ongoing exchange about whether a discovery demand had been sent previously, and whether any discovery responses had been served, as well as links to supporting documents and exhibits intended to support the discovery process.

In sum
Between November 12 and December 27, 2024, counsel for Kimberly Brasher and counsel for Walgreen Co. exchanged questions and updates about the progress, service, and provision of discovery responses in the case Kimberly Brasher v. Walgreen Co. (McLean 24-CI-00012). The record shows attempts to locate a demand for discovery, the sharing of documents via a Dropbox link to relevant exhibits, and ongoing inquiries about whether discovery responses had been served. The participants—Bryce Koon for Kimberly Brasher and Matthew Steinberg for Walgreen Co.—provided their contact details and included privilege disclosures in each message.

Case: Kimberly-Brasher-Premise-2-25-2023. Client: Kimberly Brasher. This matter concerns the claim of Kimberly Brasher against Walgreens Co. (McLean County 24-CI-00012). The exchange below reflects late-2024 counsel communications regarding discovery in the case, with Bryce Koon, Esq., of The Whaley Law Firm, corresponding with Matthew B. Steinberg, Esq., Co-Managing Partner of Quintairos, Prieto, Wood & Boyer, P.A. The electronic messages were sent with standard attorney-client privilege notices and were addressed to the named recipients, with copies to the Filevine project email for Kimberly Brasher.

The earliest dated communication in this thread occurs on November 12, 2024, when Matthew B. Steinberg wrote to Bryce Koon: “Thanks for the email and nice to meet you. I have just received the file and probably need a few days to figure out what is going on. Would you be okay if I got back to you first of next week. I see you have been waiting a bit and am sorry for that. I promise to work as quickly as possible.” This message marked the initial acknowledgement of receipt of the file and a plan to follow up after a short period of review.

On December 12, 2024, Bryce Koon followed up with Matthew Steinberg regarding the discovery requests in the case, asking, “Good afternoon counsel, Just wanted to follow up on the discovery requests in this one. Any update appreciated.” He included his Whaley Law Firm contact details and again noted the standard privilege language in the email footer.

Two days later, on December 13, 2024, Bryce sent another message to Matthew with additional documents and access to relevant materials. He began, “Good morning Matthew, Please see attached. Below is a Dropbox link to relevant documents. If you have any trouble with the link or have any questions in this regard, please let me know.” He provided a Dropbox link to a PDF titled Brasher-Demand-Exhibits.pdf and closed with thanks and his contact information, including the firm’s privilege notice.

That same day, December 13, 2024, at 9:05 AM, Matthew Steinberg replied: “Thank you. We are working on these. I can’t recall if you all have sent a demand on this one or not. If so, would you please forward as I can’t locate one in the file I received.” He again included his signature block with his title, office location in Lexington, and the firm’s multi-state presence.

Earlier in the day, December 13, 2024 at 10:13 AM, Bryce Koon sent a separate message confirming the formal delivery of documents and attaching the same Dropbox link for convenience. His message reiterated the Dropbox link and invited any questions, ending with the customary privilege notice.

On December 23, 2024, at 10:30 AM, Matthew Steinberg wrote: “Thank you all. I have now gone through the file. I see that Lee had discovery complete and verified just before he transferred the file to me. Did he ever serve these responses on you all?” He described the prior attorney (Lee) as having completed and verified the discovery before transfer and asked whether those responses had been served on the opposing side.

The chronology continued on December 27, 2024, when Bryce Koon emailed Matthew Steinberg: “Good afternoon Matthew, We have not received any discovery responses that I am aware of.” This message confirmed there had been no discovery responses in hand at that time. It also contained the Whaley Law Firm’s standard privilege disclaimer, as with prior communications.

On December 30, 2024, there were two brief exchanges. First, at 8:34 AM, Matthew Steinberg replied to Bryce: “Thanks. You will have those this week.” He again included his office’s full signature block and the multi-state firm listing. Then, at 12:33 PM, Bryce Koon responded: “Sounds good, thank you.” This final note, like the others, carried the standard attorney-client privilege language.

Throughout these exchanges, the correspondence circulated among the involved attorneys regarding discovery in Kimberly Brasher v. Walgreens Co. (McLean 24-CI-00012), with documented efforts to obtain discovery responses, reference to prior counsel’s completion and verification of discovery, and ongoing coordination about delivering and serving those responses. The communications also show that the Filevine project email for Kimberly Brasher was CC’d in the thread, and each email contained the customary privilege notices indicating that the messages were intended only for the named recipients and should not be forwarded if received in error. The parties’ representatives—W. Bryce Koon, Esq., The Whaley Law Firm, and Matthew B. Steinberg, Esq., Quintairos, Prieto, Wood & Boyer, P.A.—exchanged these updates within the weeks leading up to December 30, 2024, with the expectation that discovery responses would be exchanged within that week.

episodes.natural_language:
In the matter of Kimberly Brasher v. Walgreens Co. (McLean 24-CI-00012), counsel communications occurred between The Whaley Law Firm and Quintairos, Prieto, Wood & Boyer, P.A. over discovery in late 2024 and early 2025. The subject line for these exchanges consistently referenced the case, with the latest note identifying the case as Kimberly Brasher v. Walgreen Co. and listing the parties involved.

The first substantive thread began on December 12, 2024, when W. Bryce Koon, Esq., of The Whaley Law Firm in Louisville, Kentucky, sent a message to Matthew B. Steinberg, Co-Managing Partner of Quintairos, Prieto, Wood & Boyer, P.A., in Lexington, Kentucky, with Kimberly Brasher Premise 2/25/2023 as a cc’d recipient through the Filevine Project Email Address. The content of that initial message is not fully shown in the record, but it sets the stage for subsequent communications about discovery.

On December 13, 2024, Bryce followed up with Matthew, stating that he had attached documents and providing a Dropbox link to relevant materials for the case. He wrote: Good morning Matthew, Please see attached. Below is a Dropbox link to relevant documents. If you have any trouble with the link or have any questions in this regard, please let me know. The message included the link to Brasher-Demand-Exhibits.pdf and carried the standard attorney-client disclaimers.

Later that same day, December 13, 2024 at 9:05 a.m., Matthew replied that they were working on the materials. He asked Bryce to forward any discovery demand if one had already been sent, noting that he could not locate a demand in the file he had received. He also included his signature and firm information.

On December 23, 2024, at approximately 10:30 a.m., Matthew wrote again, thanking the recipients and reporting that he had gone through the file and observed that Lee had discovery complete and verified just before transferring the file to him. He asked whether Lee had ever served those responses on their side.

A few days later, on December 27, 2024, Bryce responded that they had not received any discovery responses to his knowledge. He reiterated the lack of receipt of those materials.

On December 30, 2024, at 8:34 a.m., Matthew replied that they would have the discovery responses that week. Bryce replied later that day at 12:33 p.m. with a brief, “Sounds good, thank you,” confirming the plan to receive the responses shortly.

The timeline continued into the new year. On January 3, 2025, at 11:30:45 a.m. Eastern Time, Bryce sent a follow-up email to counsel, stating: Good morning counsel, I may have missed an email or something, but I cannot seem to find your client’s discovery responses anywhere. I see that you filed a notice of service on 12/30/24 – is there any chance you could resend those to me? If they were mailed, there is always the chance they have not arrived yet. Any update appreciated. He concluded with his standard contact information and the firm’s attorney-client privilege disclaimer.

Throughout these exchanges, the communications consistently referenced the discovery responses and the status of service, including the observation that a notice of service had allegedly been filed on December 30, 2024, and the concern that mailed responses may not have arrived yet. The thread includes the typical attorney disclaimers and signatures, with Koon representing The Whaley Law Firm in Louisville and Steinberg representing Quintairos, Prieto, Wood & Boyer, P.A. in Lexington, as well as the cc’d Filevine Project email address for Kimberly Brasher Premise 2/25/2023.

In summary, from December 2024 through early January 2025, counsel pursued the status and delivery of the client’s discovery responses, noting that prior counsel had completed discovery before transferring the file, and coordinating expectations about receiving and resending those discovery materials to ensure they were properly served and received. The most recent request, dated January 3, 2025, sought a resend of the discovery responses due to difficulty locating them, alongside acknowledgment of a notice of service filed on December 30, 2024.
episodes.author: Bryce Koon
